subject: Re: [junit] How Junit will test all assert methods, even if one or more assert methods fails in a TestCase?
msgSnippet: Bravo! The existing weak FAQ entry I wrote on this subject will be replaced with J.B. s excellent answer. The FAQ is equal opportunity, by the way.  No
messageBody:
Bravo!

The existing weak FAQ entry I wrote on this subject will be replaced
with J.B.'s excellent answer.

The FAQ is equal opportunity, by the way. No reasonable contribution
will be denied. Your name will appear by any contribution you make. If
you disagree with J.B., then start writing.

Mike


J. B. Rainsberger wrote:

>>J. B. Rainsberger wrote:
>>
>>>>Hmmm, a lot of ink has been spilled on this question on this list.
>>>>While I don't object to your message Alexander, I'd like to motion
>>>>that we collectively refrain from reopening this discussion.
>>>>
>>>Seconded. Let's handle this one really well in the FAQ, including all
>>>opinions, and point future instances of the question to the FAQ.
>>>
>>This entry is weak in the draft FAQ right now:
>>
>>----
>>
>>Why does JUnit only report the first failure in a single test?
>>
>>A single test method may contain multiple assertions, but the test
>>method fails as soon as any of its assertions fail.
>>
>>By design, JUnit assumes there's no reason to report multiple
>>failures in a given test method. Once a test fails, it can only fail
>>more and clutter the output with side-effect failures.
>>
>
>Reporting multiple failures in a single test is generally a sign that the
>test does too much, compared to what a unit test ought to do. Usually this
>means either that the test is really a functional/acceptance/customer test
>or, if it is a unit test, then it is too big a unit test.
>
>JUnit is designed to work best with a number of small tests. It executes each
>test within a separate instance of the test class. It reports failure on each
>test. Shared setup code is most natural when sharing between tests. This is a
>design decision that permeates JUnit, and when you decide to report multiple
>failures per test, you begin to fight against JUnit. This is not recommended.
>
>Long tests are a design smell and indicate the likelihood of a design
>problem. Kent Beck is fond of saying in this case that "there is an
>opportunity to learn something about your design." We would like to see a
>pattern language develop around these problems, but it has not yet been
>written down.
>
>Finally, note that a single test with multiple assertions is isomorphic to a
>test case with multiple tests:
>
>One test method, three assertions:
>
>public class MyTestCase extends TestCase {
> public void testSomething() {
> // Set up for the test, manipulating local variables
> assertTrue(condition1);
> assertTrue(condition2);
> assertTrue(condition3);
> }
>}
>
>Three test methods, one assertion each:
>
>public class MyTestCase extends TestCase {
> // Locale variables become instance variables
>
> protected void setUp() {
> // Set up for the test, manipulating instance variables
> }
>
> public void testCondition1() {
> assertTrue(condition1);
> }
>
> public void testCondition2() {
> assertTrue(condition2);
> }
>
> public void testCondition3() {
> assertTrue(condition3);
> }
>}
>
>The resulting tests use JUnit's natural execution and reporting mechanism
>and, failure in one test does not affect the execution of the other tests.
>You generally want exactly one test to fail for any given bug, if you can
>manage it.
>
>--
